questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with persistent hypertension despite being on three different antihypertensive drugs. He also complains of muscle weakness and frequent headaches. On examination, his blood pressure is 160/110 mm of Hg, and laboratory tests reveal hypokalemia. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial test in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of hypokalemia and treatment-resistant hypertension points to a diagnosis of primary hyperaldosteronism. The initial test for this condition is the concurrent measurement of plasma renin and aldosterone, followed by the calculation of the aldosterone-renin ratio (ARR).

Primary hyperaldosteronism, also known as Conn’s syndrome, is characterized by excessive production of aldosterone by the adrenal glands, leading to sodium retention, potassium excretion, and subsequent hypertension. Drug-resistant hypertension is a hallmark of this condition. The symptom of muscle weakness in this patient is most likely due to hypokalemia.

The aldosterone-renin ratio is the most appropriate screening test for primary hyperaldosteronism, this can be followed by a saline infusion test (Option B), which is used to confirm the diagnosis of Conn’s syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Cosyntropin test detects adrenal insufficiency by measuring cortisol response to synthetic ACTH (Cosyntropin).

Option D: Measuring plasma ACTH levels helps diagnose adrenal insufficiency or Cushing’s syndrome. It is not useful in suspected hyperaldosteronism.

questions.text: A 3-weeks-old infant diagnosed with primary adrenal insufficiency presented with failure to thrive, recurrent vomiting, and hepatosplenomegaly. Radiological imaging shows bilateral adrenal calcification. Enzyme studies revealed a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase. What is the most likely disease in this case?
questions.solution:
An infant with primary adrenal insufficiency with hepatosplenomegaly, recurrent emesis, and bilateral adrenal calcification is suggestive of Wolman's disease. It is due to the deficiency of the enzyme acid lipase.

It is a lipid disorder caused by a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase (chromosome 10) which leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in the most visceral organs. It is an Autosomal recessive disease.

The child presents in the first few weeks of life with failure to thrive, vomiting, abdominal distention, steatorrhea, hepatosplenomegaly, and hyperlipidemia with extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands.No specific therapy is available and death usually occurs within 6 months of life.

questions.text:
Match the given conditions with their usual clinical presentation:
1. Conn’s syndrome a. Nausea, vomiting, normal blood pressure, normal potassium, low BUN
2. Cushing’s syndrome b. Nausea, vomiting, hypotension, hyperkalemia, high BUN
3. Addison’s disease c. Fatigue, hypertension, low potassium, low renin
4. SIADH d. Fatigue, hypertension, high sodium, high bicarbonate
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a. 

1. Conn’s syndrome c. Fatigue, hypertension, low potassium, low renin
2. Cushing’s syndrome d. Fatigue, hypertension, high sodium, high bicarbonate
3. Addison’s disease b. Nausea, vomiting, hypotension, hyperkalemia, high BUN
4. SIADH a. Nausea, vomiting, normal blood pressure, normal potassium, low BUN

Conn’s syndrome or primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by excessive production of aldosterone, which increases sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the kidneys. This results in hypertension, hypokalemia, fatigue due to electrolyte imbalance, and low renin levels due to feedback inhibition.

Cushing’s syndrome involves high levels of cortisol. This can lead to sodium retention, potassium loss, high bicarbonate, and altered glucose metabolism. This causes symptoms of hypertension, fatigue, and elevated blood glucose. 

Addison’s disease is caused due to insufficient production of cortisol and aldosterone. The lack of cortisol causes reduced gluconeogenesis and increased ACTH secretion, which in turn leads to increased potassium levels. The lack of aldosterone causes reduced sodium reabsorption and increased potassium retention. This results in symptoms of hypotension, nausea, vomiting, and elevated BUN due to impaired renal function.

SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion) involves excessive secretion of ADH despite normal or low plasma osmolality. This causes water retention, diluting serum sodium, and increasing urine osmolality. The resultant fluid overload can cause nausea, vomiting, and low BUN.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman undergoes an abdominal CT which incidentally reveals a 2 cm adrenal mass. Further tests show that it is non-functional. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
In this patient with a 2 cm non-functional adrenal mass, the most appropriate initial approach is conservative management with a follow-up CT after 6 months to monitor for any growth or changes in the adrenal mass.

Adrenal incidentalomas are asymptomatic adrenal masses detected incidentally on imaging performed for other reasons. These can be benign or malignant tumors of adrenal or extra-adrenal origin. These tumors can be functioning (secreting excess hormones) or non-functioning.

Management of an adrenal incidentaloma largely depends on its size and functional status. Incidentalomas which are small (<3 cm), benign, non-functioning tumors do not require immediate surgery. Instead, these patients should undergo a follow-up CT/MRI at 6 months to monitor for any changes or growth in the adrenal mass.

Adrenalectomy is indicated in all tumors >4 cm functional tumors, tumors showing imaging characteristics of malignancy or significant growth.

Other options: 

Option B: Medical therapy with spironolactone is not indicated for non-functional adrenal masses.

Option C: Open adrenalectomy is suggested for unilateral adrenal masses that exhibit radiological signs of malignancy.

Option D: Laparoscopic adrenalectomy is advised for unilateral adrenal masses < 6 cm in diameter that show radiological features suggesting malignancy but lack signs of local invasion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented with a history of fatigue. Examination findings are shown below. Which of the following is used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a patient presenting with fatigue and hyperpigmentation of the palms and the oral cavity (mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation), a diagnosis of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) is most likely. The test used to confirm the diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency is the ACTH stimulation test (also known as the short cosyntropin test or short Synacthen test).

ACTH stimulation test involves the administration of an exogenous, synthetic peptide that has an activity similar to ACTH on the adrenal glands. Serum cortisol levels are measured prior to, and after the administration of the synthetic peptide. Cortisol levels lower than the cut-off value indicate a failure of the adrenal glands to increase the production of cortisol in response to synthetic ACTH — thus confirming the diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency. Note that this will be seen in both primary and secondary adrenal insufficiency.

Adrenal insufficiency can be divided into:

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) is most commonly due to autoimmune adrenalitis. These patients are likely to develop other autoimmune diseases such as vitiligo, premature ovarian failure, and autoimmune thyroid disease. Other causes of Addison's disease include destruction of the adrenal gland due to infections such as TB, hemorrhage (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome due to meningococcemia) or infiltration.

Secondary adrenal insufficiency occurs due to hypothalamic-pituitary axis dysfunction. This can include iatrogenic suppression due to chronic therapy with glucocorticoids, or because of pituitary and hypothalamic tumors. Pituitary apoplexy because of hypovolemic shock during parturition (Sheehan syndrome) can also cause secondary adrenal insufficiency.

The patients present with fatigue and loss of energy. Primary adrenal insufficiency causes hyperpigmentation due to excess ACTH, which stimulates the melanocytes to produce more pigment. Hyperpigmentation is maximally seen in areas exposed to sunlight or that which undergo friction. However, secondary adrenal insufficiency presents with skin paleness due to the complete absence of ACTH. 

The diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency is established by the ACTH stimulation test as described above. Primary and secondary adrenal insufficiencies can be differentiated biochemically:

Primary adrenal insufficiency Secondary adrenal insufficiency
Serum cortisol after ACTH stimulation: low Serum cortisol after ACTH stimulation: low
Serum ACTH: high Serum ACTH: low
Plasma renin: high (minerocorticoid deficiency also present, since adrenal gland itself is not functioning) Plasma renin: normal (adrenal gland itself is functional and can be regulated by renin-angiotensin system)


Patients should also undergo screening for steroid autoantibodies and a CT scan of the adrenal glands to narrow down the cause of the adrenal insufficiency. 

Treatment is with oral hydrocortisone 15-25 mg/day in 2-3 divided doses. Long-acting agents are not preferred because they cause receptor activation even when the cortisol levels are supposed to be physiologically low in the body. Mineralocorticoid replacement is done with fludrocortisone 100-150 μg.

questions.text: A patient with a history of fatigue and lethargy is being evaluated for adrenal insufficiency. The diagnosis was confirmed using a cosyntropin stimulation test, and subsequent testing revealed low morning ACTH levels. What is the next best diagnostic test for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with adrenal insufficiency has low ACTH levels suggestive of secondary adrenal insufficiency. Thus, the next best test would be an MRI pituitary.

Secondary adrenal insufficiency results from defects in ACTH secretion by the pituitary gland or CRH secretion by the hypothalamus. In this context, an MRI of the pituitary is the most appropriate next step.

Adrenal insufficiency is the decreased production of adrenocortical hormones and is classified as primary, or secondary. Evaluation of adrenal insufficiency begins with clinical suspicion based on symptoms such as weight loss, fatigue, postural hypotension, hyperpigmentation, and hyponatremia.

Diagnosis is confirmed with a cosyntropin stimulation test, which measures the adrenal glands' response to synthetic ACTH (cosyntropin). A baseline cortisol level is obtained, followed by cosyntropin administration, with cortisol levels measured again after 30-60 minutes. In adrenal insufficiency, cortisol levels remain low despite stimulation.

Differentiation between primary and secondary causes involves measuring plasma ACTH levels. High ACTH levels indicate primary adrenal insufficiency, warranting adrenal autoantibody tests and further imaging like chest X-ray or adrenal CT to determine the cause. Low or normal ACTH levels indicate secondary adrenal insufficiency, necessitating an MRI of the pituitary to identify possible lesions or other underlying causes (in patients not taking corticosteroids). 

Other options

Option A: Adrenal autoantibodies are used to diagnose autoimmune adrenalitis, which is a cause of primary adrenal insufficiency. However, the patient's response to cosyntropin indicates secondary adrenal insufficiency.

Option B: Imaging of the adrenal glands is useful in cases of primary adrenal insufficiency to detect structural abnormalities. Since the patient likely has secondary adrenal insufficiency, this option is not the most immediate next step.

Option D: A chest X-ray might be used if there is suspicion of tuberculosis affecting the adrenal glands, but there is no indication in this patient.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding pheochromocytoma?
  1. Associated with sustained hypertension
  2. Associated with paroxysmal hypertension
  3. Associated with orthostatic hypotension
  4. Most are bilateral
  5. DOPA-PET scan can be done for localization
questions.solution:
Pheochromocytoma can present with both paroxysmal and sustained hypertension, and DOPA-PET can be used for the localization of the tumor.

Pheochromocytomas and paragangliomas are catecholamine-producing tumors that are derived from the autonomic nervous system. According to WHO terminology, the term pheochromocytoma is restricted to adrenal tumors, while the term paraganglioma is used for all the other sites.

The patients present with the classic triad of headache, sweating, and palpitations. The dominant finding seen in the patients is hypertension. Both episodic/paroxysmal and sustained hypertension can be seen in the patients. During one of these episodes, there can be arrhythmias and heart failure. Pheochromocytoma is a state of contraction of the intravascular volume. This is because increased catecholamines cause systemic vasoconstriction. Further, there is increased activity of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, causing efferent arteriolar vasoconstriction and increased filtration in the kidneys. Intravascular volume contraction causes orthostatic hypotension. 

Biochemical tests used to diagnose pheochromocytoma include 24-hour urinary catecholamines and metanephrines, and plasma catecholamines and metanephrines. T2 weighted MRI with gadolinium contrast is the investigation of choice for localization of the tumor. This is better than contrast-enhanced CT for detecting extra-adrenal tumors. Localization can also be done using MIBG and DOPA-PET scan. These agents are also useful for assessing metastatic disease.

The optimal treatment is by resection of the tumor, either by partial or complete adrenelectomy. Normal adrenal cortex preservation is important to prevent the development of Addison's disease when the tumor is present bilaterally. The pre-operative preparation consists of giving oral phenoxybenzamine for α blockade first. Oral prazosin or IV phentolamine can be given to the patient while adequate α blockade with phenoxybenzamine is awaited. α blockade is achieved first in patients with pheochromocytoma because β blockade alone will cause severe vasoconstriction because of the elevated catecholamine levels. Once α blockade is achieved, β blockers are then added.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency?
questions.solution:
11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency is associated with metabolic alkalosis, not metabolic acidosis.

It is a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia that presents with the following features:

  • Glucocorticoid deficiency:
    • Hypoglycemia
    • Hyperpigmentation around the genitals due to excess adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) secretion 
  • Mineralocorticoid excess:
    • Hypokalemia
    • Hypertension
    • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Adrenal androgen excess
    • Virilization in females
    • Precocious puberty in males

questions.text: The following changes were observed on the administration of a drug. Which of the following is the likely drug?
questions.solution:
Since the administration of the given drug shows an increase in systolic, diastolic, and mean arterial pressure, along with reflex bradycardia, the drug is likely to be norepinephrine.

Norepinephrine acts on α1 and β1 receptors to increase the peripheral vascular resistance and stroke volume respectively. This causes an increase in diastolic, systolic, and mean arterial pressure. Increased mean arterial pressure leads to reflex bradycardia.


Epinephrine (option A) acts on α1, β1, and β2 receptors. There is a rise in systolic BP, but a fall in the diastolic BP — vascular β2 receptors are more sensitive than α1 receptors, leading to vasodilation. There is generally a small rise in the mean arterial pressure. The heart rate increases due to β1 action.

Isoproterenol (option D) acts on β receptors, causing predominantly β2 mediated vasodilation and resultant reflex tachycardia.

Propranolol (option C) is a β-blocker and will cause a decrease in the BP and heart rate.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most sensitive test to distinguish between Cushing’s disease from ectopic ACTH production?
questions.solution:
The best test to differentiate Cushing’s disease from Ectopic ACTH production is Inferior petrosal sinus sampling (IPSS) owing to its high sensitivity (95%) and specificity (99%). 

During IPSS, catheters are placed in the inferior petrosal sinuses, which drain blood directly from the pituitary gland. Blood samples are collected from these sinuses and from a peripheral vein to measure ACTH levels.

The principle of IPSS is based on the anatomical and functional characteristics of the pituitary gland:

Central-to-Peripheral Gradient: The pituitary gland directly releases ACTH into the venous blood that drains through the inferior petrosal sinuses. Therefore, in cases of Cushing's disease (where the source of excess ACTH is a pituitary adenoma), ACTH levels will be significantly higher in the blood samples taken from the inferior petrosal sinuses compared to the peripheral blood.

Baseline Ratio: A central-to-peripheral ACTH ratio greater than 2 at baseline indicates the pituitary is the primary source of excess ACTH rather than from an ectopic source.

Stimulated Ratio: After the administration of CRH (corticotropin-releasing hormone), which stimulates ACTH secretion by the pituitary gland, a central-to-peripheral ACTH ratio greater than 3 further confirms a pituitary source. This is because CRH administration would cause a more pronounced increase in ACTH release from a pituitary adenoma compared to ectopic sources.

The absence of such a gradient (a ratio less than the thresholds mentioned) suggests that the source of excess ACTH is not the pituitary gland, but rather an ectopic source elsewhere in the body.

MRI pituitary is not sensitive enough to detect small pituitary ACTH-secreting adenomas (<2 mm).

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: Shown below is a section taken from a specimen of an adrenal gland. Which of the following results in a decrease in the hormone exclusively secreted by the layer marked as '1'?
questions.solution:
In the above image, the layer marked as '1' is zona glomerulosa, and aldosterone is exclusively secreted by this layer. Hypernatremia decreases aldosterone secretion. 

The zona glomerulosa is a thin layer of cells that lies just underneath the capsule of the adrenal gland.

The following factors are known to play roles in the regulation of aldosterone: 

  • Hyperkalemia increases aldosterone secretion.
  • Increased angiotensin II concentration increases aldosterone secretion.
  • Hypernatremia concentration in the extracellular fluid slightly decreases aldosterone secretion.
  • ACTH from the anterior pituitary gland is necessary for aldosterone secretion but has minimal effect in physiological conditions.
  • Increased sodium ion concentration in the extracellular fluid decreases aldosterone secretion.

Other options:

The adrenal cortex has three zones. From outer to inner, they are:

  • Zona glomerulosa: Secretes mineralocorticoids (Aldosterone)
  • Zona fasiculata: Secretes glucocorticoids (Cortisol)
  • Zona reticularis: Secretes sex steroids

The adrenal medulla secretes catecholamines.

questions.text: CRH responsiveness and residual ACTH suppression by high-dose dexamethasone are seen in hypercortisolism due to:
questions.solution:
CRH responsiveness is seen only in hypercortisolism which is due to a pituitary cause.

Physiologically, CRH released from the hypothalamus has a stimulatory effect on the pituitary corticotropic cells, thus producing ACTH.

Hypercortisolism may be endogenous or iatrogenic.

  • Iatrogenic hypercortisolism is not affected by dynamic testing
  • Endogenous hypercortisolism may be ACTH-dependent or ACTH-independent

ACTH-dependent Cushing’s syndrome can be further classified by dynamic testing:

Pituitary cause:

  • CRH test – Positive. ACTH increase > 40% at 15–30 min + cortisol increase >20% at 45–60 min after CRH 100 μg IV
  • High-dose dexamethasone suppression test - Positive. Cortisol suppression >50% after q6h 2 mg dexamethasone administration for 2 days

Ectopic cause:

  • CRH test - Negative
  • High-dose dexamethasone suppression test - Negative

questions.text: A 50-year-old female is suspected to have Cushing's syndrome. Which of the following investigations is not performed until a confirmatory diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established?

choices.text: Measurement of 24 hours urinary free cortisol

questions.solution:
The high-dose dexamethasone suppression test is done only after a diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established in a patient.

The high-dose dexamethasone suppression test is used in patients with confirmed Cushing syndrome. It helps to differentiate between Cushing's disease (i.e a pituitary cause) and ectopic ACTH production.

The basis for this test is that in subjects with Cushing disease, a higher dose of dexamethasone (usually 8 mg) is required to suppress ACTH secretion and drop cortisol levels in serum, urine, and saliva.

Standard 2-day (high dose) dexamethasone suppression test:

  • Serum cortisol level and/or 24-hour urinary free cortisol is measured as a baseline, and then dexamethasone 2 mg orally is taken every 6 hours for 48 hours; urine for free cortisol is collected during the test, and serum cortisol is checked 6 hours after the last dose. The suppression of cortisol secretion to >50 % of the baseline is considered positive and indicative of Cushing's disease

The following four investigations are used to establish an initial diagnosis of endogenous Cushing's syndrome as per the clinical guidelines of the endocrine society.

  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol (increased 3x above normal)
  • Midnight salivary cortisol ( >5nmol/L)
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression (plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L at 8-9 AM after 1 mg dexamethasone at 11 PM)
  • Standard 2-day (low dose) dexamethasone suppression test (plasma cortisol > 50 nmol/L after 0.5 mg dexamethasone 6th hourly for 48 hours).

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with altered mental status. Lab workup shows serum sodium of 110 mEq/L and negative alcohol and toxicology screens. An opacity in the left lower lung is seen on the chest X-Ray. What is the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) with altered mental status, and the management in this patient is 3% saline.

SIADH occurs due to excessive production of ADH (or vasopressin). The most common cause are neuroendocrine neoplasms like small cell lung carcinoma (at least half the cases) and carcinoids.

Symptoms include decreased thirst, lethargy, nausea, confusion, depressed mental status, and seizures. However, most patients are asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally due to the presence of hyponatremia. The severity of symptoms indicates the severity of hyponatremia. Hyponatremia occurs with decreased serum osmolality and normal or increased urine osmolality.

Management includes correction of hyponatremia and treatment of the underlying malignancy. Since hyponatremia develops over several weeks to months, it should be corrected gradually at a rate of 0.5–1 meq/L/h to prevent brain dehydration and central pontine myelinolysis (an acute life-threatening neurological syndrome characterized by quadriparesis, ataxia, and abnormal extraocular movements).

  • Hypervolemic hyponatremia:
    • Fluid restriction to less than urine output, plus insensible losses, with strict monitoring of fluid intake in mild cases
    • Vasopressin receptor antagonists, like conivaptan and tolvaptan, in severe cases

Demeclocycline, an inhibitor of vasopressin, is not preferred due to its relatively slower onset of action (1–2 weeks).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a history of palpitations, panic attacks, and difficulty swallowing. Examination reveals a heart rate of 110 bpm, a blood pressure of 156/100 mmHg, and a neck swelling that moves with swallowing. Labs show hypercalcemia, elevated calcitonin, and parathormone levels and an MRI shows bilateral adrenal masses. What gene is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A (MEN) due to a gain of function mutation of RET proto-oncogene. 

Palpitations, panic attacks, tachycardia, hypertension with bilateral adrenal masses suggest the presence of a pheochromocytoma. Difficulty swallowing and a neck swelling that moves with swallowing along with elevated calcitonin indicated medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. Hypercalcemia and elevated PTH could reflect parathyroid hyperplasia. Pheochromocytoma, medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, and parathyroid hyperplasia is seen in MEN 2A.

MEN type 2 is classified into MEN 2A and MEN 2B. 

MEN 2A is also called Sipple syndrome and characterized by

  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid
  • Parathyroid hyperplasia.

MEN 2B is characterized by

  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid
  • Pheochromocytoma.
  • Mucosal neuromas of lips and tongue, intestinal ganglioneuromas, marfanoid habitus, and lax joints.
  • Parathyroid hyperplasia is absent. 

Other options:

Option B: Mutations in the MEN1 tumor suppressor gene lead to MEN 1, also called Wermer syndrome.  It is characterized by

  • Parathyroid hyperplasia or adenoma
  • Pancreas - endocrine tumors
  • Pituitary - the most common anterior pituitary tumor is prolactinoma

Option D: CDKN1B mutations cause MEN 4. This is characterized by clinical features similar to MEN 1.

Option A: p53 tumor suppressor gene mutations can lead to Li Fraumeni syndrome. This is an autosomal dominant hereditary cancer disorder. Patients develop multiple cancers at a young age such as sarcomas, breast cancer, brain tumors, and leukemias.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

questions.text: The graph below shows the variations in the levels of an adrenocortical hormone over a period of 24 hours. Excessive synthesis of this hormone can lead to which of the following features?
questions.solution:
The adrenocortical hormone likely plotted above is cortisol as the graph shows a diurnal variation with the maximum peak occurring around 8.00 AM. Excessive synthesis of this hormone leads to decreased cellular immunity. 

Cortisol suppresses cellular immunity by inhibiting the production of IL-2 and decreasing the proliferation of T-lymphocytes. This action is used for suppressing immunity by administering exogenous glucocorticoids to reduce the rejection reactions during transplantation.  

Cortisol is secreted in a pulsatile fashion and has a diurnal variation in its level. The maximum level occurs in the morning just before awakening (at around 8.00 AM). It gradually declines later and the lowest levels are seen in the evening and midnight, after falling asleep. 

Cortisol is the major glucocorticoid hormone synthesized in the adrenal cortex, mainly in the zona fasciculata layer. Its actions are - 

i) Metabolic effects:

  • On carbohydrates: It stimulates gluconeogenesis, increases glycogen synthesis, and decreases the utilization of glucose in peripheral tissues. Thus, excess stimulation of cortisol causes hyperglycemia. 
  • On fat: Increases lipolysis. 
  • On protein: Exerts a catabolic effect and causes proteolysis
  • Effect on appetite: Increases the appetite and food intake by inducing the synthesis of neuropeptide-Y.

ii) Anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects:

  • Induce the synthesis of lipocortin, an inhibitor of phospholipase A2
  • Inhibit the release of histamine and serotonin 
  • Inhibit the production of IL-2 and T lymphocytes, and depresses cellular immunity

iii) Maintenance of vascular responsiveness to catecholamines:

  • Cortisol up-regulates α1 receptors on arterioles, increasing their sensitivity to the vasoconstrictor effect of norepinephrine, thereby causing hypertension in hypercortisolism. 

iv) Bone formation inhibition by decreasing the type 1 collagen synthesis, intestinal calcium absorption, and osteoblastic activity. 

v) In the central nervous system, cortisol receptors are majorly found in the limbic system. Hence, stimulation of this decreases the rapid eye movement during sleep and increases awake time. Thus, high levels of cortisol are seen in the morning just before awakening.

questions.text: A woman presents with a 2-month history of fatigue, muscle weakness, headaches, and palpitations. Her pulse is 75/min, and her blood pressure is 175/92 mm Hg. Physical examination is unremarkable and lab results show serum potassium of 2.8  mEq/L, increased plasma aldosterone levels, and suppressed plasma renin activity. Which of the following tests can confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with lab findings suggests primary hyperaldosteronism. The diagnosis can be confirmed via saline infusion test.

The saline infusion test is a confirmatory test that involves administering intravenous saline to suppress aldosterone secretion. In normal physiology, increased intravascular volume from saline should suppress aldosterone production. However, in primary hyperaldosteronism, aldosterone levels remain elevated despite saline infusion, confirming autonomous aldosterone production.

Primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn syndrome), is characterized by excessive production of aldosterone by the adrenal glands. Patients commonly present with fatigue, muscle weakness, headaches, palpitations, and high blood pressure. Hypokalemia can cause muscle cramps, weakness, and even paralysis in severe cases. The diagnosis is suspected based on clinical presentation and laboratory findings of elevated plasma aldosterone and suppressed plasma renin activity

Approach to diagnosing hyperaldosteronism:

Evaluation begins with measuring plasma aldosterone concentration (PAC) and plasma renin activity (PRA). Elevated PAC and low PRA  suggest primary hyperaldosteronism. E.g. an adrenal mass that secretes aldosterone will increase PAC and intravascular volume but PRA is reduced because of negative feedback on the JG apparatus.

Elevated PAC and PRA indicate hyperaldosteronism due to a secondary cause such as renal artery stenosis in which reduced perfusion to the kidney will activate RAAS and increase both renin and aldosterone.

Low levels of PAC and PRA suggest pseudo-hyperaldosteronism. e.g. The excess cortisol (which has mineralocorticoid activity) in Cushing's will cause symptoms of mineralocorticoid excess but renin and angiotensin will be low because of negative feedback on the RAAS system.

Other options: 

Option A: The dexamethasone suppression test is test is used for diagnosing Cushing syndrome, not primary hyperaldosteronism.

Option C: An MRI brain would be useful to evaluate for pituitary adenomas. However, this patient's symptoms make a diagnosis of an aldosterone secreting tumor in the adrenal more likely.

Option D: Renal duplex scan is used to diagnose renal artery stenosis, which can cause secondary hyperaldosteronism.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought with complaints of abdominal distension for the last 1 month. On examination, an irregular mass is palpated, which is crossing the midline. The patient's blood pressure is normal. Urine examination shows the presence of vanillylmandelic acid and homovanillic acid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a child presenting with a large abdominal mass with normal blood pressure and vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA) present in the urine, a diagnosis of neuroblastoma is most likely.

Neuroblastoma is the most frequently diagnosed malignancy in infancy. It most commonly arises from the adrenal glands, followed by sites along the sympathetic chain, such as the paravertebral region of the abdomen and posterior mediastinum. Neuroblastoma is derived from primordial neural crest cells which populate these sites. In young children, they present as large abdominal masses with fever and weight loss. They can also metastasize widely and present with symptoms related to other systems. 

90% of neuroblastoma produce catecholamines. Urinary levels of VMA and HVA act as important tumor markers and help in making the diagnosis of the disease. Despite the elaboration of catecholamines, hypertension is less frequent in these tumors compared to pheochromocytoma. Histologically, neuroblastoma show small, primitive-appearing cells with dark nuclei — and thus may be difficult to differentiate from other small round blue cell tumors. The background shows faintly eosinophilic fibrillary material (neuropil) which represents the neuritic processes of the primitive neuroblasts. Around the neuropil, the tumor cells are arranged concentrically. This is referred to as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes.

Other options:

Option A: The dominant clinical feature in pheochromocytoma is hypertension. Most patients have paroxysmal episodes, which are abrupt elevations in blood pressure. They are accompanied by tachycardia, palpitations, headache, and sweating. Lab diagnosis of pheochromocytoma is based on the demonstration of increased urinary excretion of free catecholamines and their metabolites such as VMA.

Option B: Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) usually presents as a unilateral abdominal mass, abdominal pain, hypertension, and gross hematuria. Wilms tumor thrombus can extend into the inferior vena cava and the right atrium. Laboratory findings that can be seen include polycythemia and thrombocytosis.

Option D: Hepatoblastoma presents as an asymptomatic mass in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. It mostly arises from the right lobe of the liver. Patients have non-specific symptoms such as fever, fatigue, weight loss, and anorexia. A biopsy of the liver mass is necessary to make the diagnosis. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a useful tumor marker that is used in diagnosis and monitoring.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man collapses during a family vacation. At the hospital, blood pressure is found to be 86/52 mm Hg, and random blood sugar is 49 mg/dl. His wife says that he has been on treatment for Addison's disease for two years but had forgotten to pack his medication for the trip. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of an adrenal crisis triggered by missed medication. In this patient who is a known case of adrenal insufficiency, IV hydrocortisone is the drug of choice.

However, in patients with newly diagnosed adrenal insufficiency, dexamethasone is used for the treatment of adrenal crisis. This is because dexamethasone is not measured in cortisol assays and would not interfere with the diagnostic tests, whereas hydrocortisone interferes with cortisol assays.

Acute adrenal insufficiency requires the immediate initiation of the following therapeutic strategies:

  • Rehydration - saline infusion at an initial rate of 1 L/h with continuous cardiac monitoring.
  • Glucocorticoid replacement - bolus injection of 100 mg hydrocortisone, followed by the maintenance dose of 100–200 mg over 24h.
  • Mineralocorticoid replacement - initiated once the daily hydrocortisone dose has been reduced to <50 mg as higher doses of hydrocortisone have sufficient mineralocorticoid action.

questions.text: A patient presents with a 3-month history of unintentional weight gain and fatigue. An exam reveals high blood pressure (149/88 mm Hg), central obesity, and abdominal striae. Lab results show elevated 24-hour urinary-free cortisol and suppressed serum ACTH. Which test would most likely confirm the underlying cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms and lab findings indicate hypercortisolism, likely Cushing's syndrome. The suppressed ACTH suggests that the source of cortisol is ACTH-independent, often due to an adrenal mass which can be confirmed with an unenhanced CT scan of the abdomen.

The diagnostic evaluation for Cushing's syndrome begins with confirming hypercortisolism through tests such as the 24-hour urinary free cortisol test, overnight dexamethasone suppression test, or midnight salivary cortisol test. Once hypercortisolism is confirmed, the next step is determining whether the cause is ACTH-dependent or ACTH-independent. This is done by measuring plasma ACTH levels.

If ACTH levels are suppressed it indicates an ACTH-independent cause, typically suggesting an adrenal source. Imaging studies, such as a CT scan of the abdomen, are performed to identify any adrenal masses (e.g., adenomas, carcinomas, or hyperplasia).

If ACTH levels are elevated or normal it suggests an ACTH-dependent cause, possibly due to a pituitary adenoma (Cushing's disease) or ectopic ACTH production. Further evaluation includes a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test and a CRH stimulation test. If cortisol levels decrease significantly after high-dose dexamethasone and the CRH test is positive, it suggests a pituitary source (Cushing's disease) which can be confirmed with an MRI. If cortisol levels are not suppressed, and the CRH test is negative the patient should be evaluated for ectopic ACTH production. In case of equivocal results, an Inferior petrosal sinus sampling may be performed to differentiate the two causes.


Other options: 

Option A: Inferior petrosal sinus sampling is used to differentiate between pituitary and ectopic sources of ACTH in ACTH-dependent Cushing's

Option C: High-dose dexamethasone suppression test differentiates pituitary and ectopic ACTH production in ACTH-dependent Cushing's.

Option D: A CT scan of the chest may be used to identify ectopic ACTH source, most commonly small cell lung carcinoma, which is unlikely given the suppressed ACTH levels.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.
